message.text:
Sorry, but latexindent.exe did not succeed for the following reason: MiKTeX could not find the script engine 'perl' which is required to execute 'latexindent'. Remedy: Make sure 'perl' is installed on your system. The log file hopefully contains the information to get MiKTeX going again: C:\Users\andrew\AppData\Local\MiKTeX\miktex\log\latexindent.log For more information, visit: https://miktex.org/kb/fix-script-engine-not-found

install this to let me format my document

parts.text:
Sorry, but latexindent.exe did not succeed for the following reason: MiKTeX could not find the script engine 'perl' which is required to execute 'latexindent'. Remedy: Make sure 'perl' is installed on your system. The log file hopefully contains the information to get MiKTeX going again: C:\Users\andrew\AppData\Local\MiKTeX\miktex\log\latexindent.log For more information, visit: https://miktex.org/kb/fix-script-engine-not-found

install this to let me format my document

response.value:
The user is getting an error when trying to use `latexindent.exe` which requires Perl. They want me to install Perl so they can format their LaTeX document.

The error message indicates that MiKTeX is looking for Perl to run the latexindent script. I need to help install Perl on Windows.

For Windows, the most common way to install Perl is:
1. Strawberry Perl - a Perl distribution for Windows
2. ActivePerl - another Windows Perl distribution

Strawberry Perl is free and commonly recommended. I should install it using PowerShell.

Let me check if Perl is already installed first, and if not, install Strawberry Perl using chocolatey (if available) or download it directly.

Steps:
1. Check if Perl is already installed
2. If not, install it (preferably using chocolatey if available, otherwise guide for manual installation)
3. Verify the installation

Let me start by checking if Perl exists and if chocolatey is available.
response.generatedTitle: Checked Perl installation and chocolatey availability

response.value: I'll help you install Perl so you can use latexindent for formatting your LaTeX document. Let me check the current state and install Perl.

message.value: This will continue to poll for output to determine when the terminal becomes idle for up to 2 minutes.

response.value: The installation needs administrator privileges. Let me try an alternative approach - I'll download and install Strawberry Perl directly:

commandLine.original: $url = "https://strawberryperl.com/download/5.38.2.2/strawberry-perl-5.38.2.2-64bit.msi"; $output = "$env:TEMP\strawberry-perl.msi"; Write-Host "Downloading Strawberry Perl..."; Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $url -OutFile $output; Write-Host "Starting installation (this will open an installer window)..."; Start-Process msiexec.exe -ArgumentList "/i `"$output`" /qn /norestart" -Wait -NoNewWindow; Write-Host "Installation complete!"

response.value: The environment variables need to be refreshed properly. Let me check where Strawberry Perl was installed and manually add it to the PATH:

commandLine.original: if (Test-Path "C:\Strawberry\perl\bin\perl.exe") { Write-Host "Found at C:\Strawberry\perl\bin\perl.exe"; $env:Path = "C:\Strawberry\c\bin;C:\Strawberry\perl\site\bin;C:\Strawberry\perl\bin;" + $env:Path; perl --version } else { Write-Host "Checking common locations..."; Get-ChildItem -Path "C:\Program Files" -Filter "perl.exe" -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Select-Object -First 1 -ExpandProperty FullName }

response.value: Interesting - Git for Windows includes a Perl, but it might not have all the modules needed. Let me check both locations and also verify if the MSI installation actually completed:

commandLine.original: Write-Host "Checking installation status..."; Write-Host ""; Write-Host "1. Checking C:\Strawberry:"; Test-Path "C:\Strawberry\perl\bin\perl.exe"; Write-Host ""; Write-Host "2. Git Perl:"; Test-Path "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\perl.exe"; Write-Host ""; Write-Host "3. Checking if MSI file exists:"; Test-Path "$env:TEMP\strawberry-perl.msi"; Write-Host ""; Write-Host "4. Testing Git's Perl:"; & "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\perl.exe" --version

response.value: Good! Now I need to make this permanent by adding Git's Perl to the system PATH. Let me do that:

commandLine.original: $userPath = [Environment]::GetEnvironmentVariable("Path", "User"); if ($userPath -notlike "*Git\usr\bin*") { $newPath = "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin;" + $userPath; [Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable("Path", $newPath, "User"); Write-Host "Git Perl added to user PATH successfully!"; Write-Host "The change will take effect in new terminal sessions."; $env:Path = "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin;" + $env:Path; Write-Host ""; Write-Host "Testing in current session:"; perl --version | Select-Object -First 3 } else { Write-Host "Git Perl is already in PATH" }
